articles.headline: Health Care Premiums Rise Slightly
articles.snippet: A study by the Kaiser Family Foundation found that a family with employer-provided health insurance now pays just under $16,000 in annual premiums, an increase of about 4 percent from a year ago.
articles.abstract: A study by the Kaiser Family Foundation found that a family with employer-provided health insurance now pays just under $16,000 in annual premiums, an increase of about 4 percent from a year ago.
articles.lead_paragraph: A family with employer-provided health insurance now pays just under $16,000 in annual premiums, an increase of about 4 percent over a year ago, according to a study released Tuesday by the nonprofit Kaiser Family Foundation.

articles.headline: Whistle-Blower Awarded $104 Million by I.R.S.
articles.snippet: Bradley Birkenfeld, who got out of jail last month after serving time for helping Americans dodge taxes, received a lavish bonus for his role in exposing tax schemes at UBS.
articles.abstract: Bradley Birkenfeld, who got out of jail last month after serving time for helping Americans dodge taxes, received a lavish bonus for his role in exposing tax schemes at UBS.

articles.headline: Should the 401(k) Be Reformed or Replaced?
articles.snippet: Less than half of the nation’s private sector workers are in 401(k) plans and 40 percent of businesses do not even offer them, leading experts and economists to question the value of the system.
articles.abstract: Less than half of the nation’s private sector workers are in 401(k) plans and 40 percent of businesses do not even offer them, leading experts and economists to question the value of the system.
articles.lead_paragraph: JOHN GREENE worked for 30 years at an Oscar Mayer plant in Madison, Wis., deboning hams and loading boxes of hot dogs. His 401(k) plan grew to $60,000, and soon after retiring he began withdrawing $3,600 a year from it, money that allowed him and his wife to take what he called a wondrous two-week trip to Scotland, his ancestral homeland.

articles.headline: A Silver Tinge to the Political Ring
articles.snippet: Organizations on both sides of the political spectrum are reporting increasing involvement in campaign activities by voters of retirement age.
articles.abstract: Organizations on both sides of the political spectrum are reporting increasing involvement in campaign activities by voters of retirement age.
articles.lead_paragraph: HAVING made his fortune in advertising and the television talk show industry, Bob Turner was enjoying a wealth of retirement pursuits — he played golf and tennis, had a home on the beach and a weekend ski house, five children, 13 grandchildren and a tight circle of longtime friends, and kept a toe in the business world with seats on a few boards.

articles.headline: Taxes Show One Way to Save Fuel
articles.snippet: Some economists say that new fuel-efficiency standards for cars and trucks will do less good for the environment than a straight tax on gasoline.
articles.abstract: Some economists say that new fuel-efficiency standards for cars and trucks will do less good for the environment than a straight tax on gasoline.
articles.lead_paragraph: Just the other day, President Obama unveiled another example of how our hostility to anything that even remotely looks like a tax is leading us down the wrong path, ultimately making us worse off.

articles.headline: Economic Stimulus as the Election Nears? It’s Been Done Before
articles.snippet: The Federal Reserve said it does not consider politics when setting policy, but it is again poised to announce an economic stimulus effort during an election season.
articles.abstract: The Federal Reserve said it does not consider politics when setting policy, but it is again poised to announce an economic stimulus effort during an election season.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In September 1992, the Federal Reserve culminated a long-running effort to stimulate the sluggish economy by cutting its benchmark interest rate to 3 percent, the lowest level it had reached in almost three decades.

articles.headline: The Fire HD: More Soot Than Sparks
articles.snippet: Amazon says its Kindle Fire HD is “the best tablet at any price.” But there’s no GPS, no to-do list, no notes app. What’s the attraction?
articles.abstract: Amazon says its Kindle Fire HD is “the best tablet at any price.” But there’s no GPS, no to-do list, no notes app. What’s the attraction?
articles.lead_paragraph: I’m not exactly sure what’s been seeping into the water supply at Amazon’s Seattle offices, but it’s making the executives a little loopy.

articles.headline: Dissecting Romney’s Vietnam Stance at Stanford
articles.snippet: Mitt Romney’s position in favor of the war during his freshman year reflected his family’s views and his faith in traditional values but later shifted markedly.
articles.abstract: Mitt Romney’s position in favor of the war during his freshman year reflected his family’s views and his faith in traditional values but later shifted markedly.
articles.lead_paragraph: It was late November 1965 when the poet Allen Ginsberg ignited the flower-power movement in Berkeley, Calif., urging protesters against the Vietnam War to greet the police with blossoms, not rocks. A few miles south, at buttoned-down Stanford University, young men would exchange chinos for jeans that academic year. An antiwar activist would become student body president; anti-draft protesters would occupy the university president’s office.

articles.headline: Equity Firms Like Bain Are Depicted as Colluding
articles.snippet: Heavily redacted documents showed top private equity firms agreeing among themselves on which would bid on takeover targets.
articles.abstract: Heavily redacted documents showed top private equity firms agreeing among themselves on which would bid on takeover targets.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In court documents that lawyers for Bain Capital sought to keep secret, the company and other leading private equity firms are depicted as unofficial partners in a bid-rigging conspiracy aimed at holding down the prices of businesses they were seeking to buy.
articles.byline: By Eric Lichtblau and Peter Lattman

articles.headline: New Breed of Robotics Aims to Help People Walk Again
articles.snippet: Several companies and research labs are working on wearable robots to help disabled people walk or to make the human body superhuman.
articles.abstract: Several companies and research labs are working on wearable robots to help disabled people walk or to make the human body superhuman.
articles.lead_paragraph: RICHMOND, Calif. — When Joey Abicca pokes a metal crutch into the ground with his right arm, tiny motors start whirling around his left leg, lifting it and moving it forward. When he does the same with his left arm, the motors whir to life again and his right leg takes a step. The metallic whine is like something out of the movie “RoboCop.”

articles.headline: Amazon, Forced to Collect a Tax, Is Adding Roots
articles.snippet: By building warehouses across the country, the retailer hopes to cut as much as a day off its two-day shipping times.
articles.abstract: By building warehouses across the country, the retailer hopes to cut as much as a day off its two-day shipping times.
articles.lead_paragraph: PATTERSON, Calif. — At the moment, it is little more than dirt and gravel. But a sunbaked field at the edge of this farming town will play a significant role in one of the most ambitious retailing ventures of the era: the relentless quest by the online mall Amazon.com to become all things to all shoppers.

articles.headline: Beck Takes His Conservative Internet Shows to the Dish Network
articles.snippet: The conservative talk show host, Glenn Beck, is taking his show, TheBlaze TV, to the satellite television network and plans for it to be available on cable TV, too.
articles.abstract: The conservative talk show host, Glenn Beck, is taking his show, TheBlaze TV, to the satellite television network and plans for it to be available on cable TV, too.
articles.lead_paragraph: Glenn Beck is bringing his brand of conservative commentary back to the television set.

articles.headline: Weary of Crisis, but Wary of Change
articles.snippet: A proposal to give the European Union more control over banking has stirred up dissent from countries that have doubts about the plan’s practicality.
articles.abstract: A proposal to give the European Union more control over banking has stirred up dissent from countries that have doubts about the plan’s practicality.
articles.lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — The European Commission president, José Manuel Barroso, described the proposal for a single supervisor for the region’s banks on Wednesday as the first step in a renewed drive for a federally unified Europe.
articles.byline: By James Kanter and Stephen Castle

articles.headline: Libya Attack Brings Challenges for U.S.
articles.snippet: The violent deaths of four American diplomatic personnel in Libya provoked an uproar in Washington on Wednesday, presenting new challenges in the volatile Middle East less than two months before the presidential election.
articles.abstract: The violent deaths of four American diplomatic personnel in Libya provoked an uproar in Washington on Wednesday, presenting new challenges in the volatile Middle East less than two months before the presidential election.
articles.lead_paragraph: CAIRO — Islamist militants armed with antiaircraft weapons and rocket-propelled grenades stormed a lightly defended United States diplomatic mission in Benghazi, Libya, late Tuesday, killing the American ambassador and three members of his staff and raising questions about the radicalization of countries swept up in the Arab Spring.
articles.byline: By David D. Kirkpatrick and Steven Lee Myers
